column1: action.buoyancy.age_max.description="Maximum age [day] for adding buoyancy effect to the particle. If the growth process is activated (see Biology/Growth)
column2: this parameter is ignored by the application and the buoyancy only operates during the egg stage."

column1: action.buoyancy.class_name.description="The Java class called by the application to implement this action."

action.buoyancy.density_file.description="Particle density as an age function. The parameter is the pathname of CSV file (semicolon separator) that contains two columns. Headers Time(hour);Density(g/cm3). If this parameter is left void
column2: ichthyop assumes constant particle density."

column1: action.buoyancy.description="Block of options that control the buoyancy process. This block can be enabled for 3D simulations only. It requires sea water salinity and sea water temperature fields to compute sea water density. Do not activate this process unless you know that the hydrodynamic dataset provides both variables."

column2: "density_file"
if density is superior to sea water density
column4: if density is inferior to sea water density
column5: particle will go up to the surface. If you want to force particles to keep close surface
column7: for instance. This parameter is ignored when a density file (density as age function
column8: refer to next parameter for details) is provided."

column2: "low"

column1: action.buoyancy.priority.description="Level of priority of the action (comparatively to other actions). Each time step
column2: a high priority action will be called by the application before than a low priority action. Actions with same level of priority will be called without any specific order."

column1: action.buoyancy.salinity_field.description="The name of the salinity variable (case sensitive) in the hydrodynamic dataset."

action.growth.class_name.description="The Java class called by the application to implement this action."
action.growth.coeff1.description="Value of the first coefficient of the growth function (detailed in the block description)"
action.growth.coeff2.description="Value of the second coefficient of the growth function (detailed in the block description)"
action.growth.description="Block of options for setting up the growth model. It simulates the growth in length of particles as a function of water temperature. Length increases linearly with time
column2: at a growth rate that is a linear function of temperature: length(t + dt) = length(t) + (growth_coeff1 + growth_coeff2 * max(temp

column1: action.growth.length_tracker.description="If true the application adds a length variable in the NetCDF output file."

column2: "coeff2"
"low"

column1: action.growth.priority.description="Level of priority of the action (comparatively to other actions). Each time step
column2: a high priority action will be called by the application before than a low priority action. Actions with same level of priority will be called without any specific order."

column1: action.growth.stage_tracker.description="If true the application adds a stage variable in the NetCDF output file."
action.growth.temperature_field.description="The name of the temperature variable (case sensitive) in the hydrodynamic dataset."
action.growth.threshold_temp.description="Threshold temperature [Celsius degree] for the sea water. It ensures that the particles keep growing with a minimum rate
column2: though they are facing colder sea water."

column1: action.hdisp.class_name.description="The Java class called by the application to implement this action."
action.hdisp.description="Block of options that control the horizontal dispersion process. Horizontal dispersion has been implemented following Peliz et al. (2007)"

column2: Peliz defined a lagrangian horizontal diffusion coefficient Kh = pow(epsilon
column6: with epsilon the turbulent dissipation rate [meter2/second3] and l the lenght of the grid cell (l is determined by the application). Monin and Ozmidov suggested epsilon = 1e-9. Make sure you have read and understood Monin and Ozmidovs paper before changing this value."

column2: "class_name"
"low"

column1: action.hdisp.priority.description="Level of priority of the action (comparatively to other actions). Each time step
column2: a high priority action will be called by the application before than a low priority action. Actions with same level of priority will be called without any specific order."

column1: action.lethal_temp.class_name.description="The Java class called by the application to implement this action."

action.lethal_temp.description="Block of option for setting up the lower lethal water temperature for the particles. The tool distinguishes between eggs and larvae lethal temperatures when the growth process is activated."
action.lethal_temp.lethal_temperature_egg.description="Lower lethal water temperature [Celsius degree] for the particles. If the growth process is active
column2: this parameter only affects particles at egg stage."

column1: action.lethal_temp.lethal_temperature_larva.description="Lower lethal water temperature [Celsius degree] for particles at larva stage (yolk-sac and feeding larva). This parameter is ignored by the application when the growth process is idle."

column2: "lethal_temperature_larva"
"low"

column1: action.lethal_temp.priority.description="Level of priority of the action (comparatively to other actions). Each time step
column2: a high priority action will be called by the application before than a low priority action. Actions with same level of priority will be called without any specific order."

column1: action.lethal_temp.temp_tracker.description="If true the application adds a temperature variable in the NetCDF output file. Setting to false does not guarantee the temperature variable will not be recorded in the NetCDF output file because it migt be required by another module."
action.lethal_temp.temperature_field.description="The name of the temperature variable (case sensitive) in the hydrodynamic dataset."

action.migration.age_min.description="If the growth procedure is activated (See biology section) then the DVM operates during the larvae stages (yolk-sac and feeding larva) and this parameter is ignored by the application. If not migration only operates after this minimum age [day]."
action.migration.class_name.description="The Java class called by the application to implement this action."
action.migration.daytime_depth.description="Set the depth [meter] of the particle during daytime. Daytime period starts at sunrise and ends at sunset. Depth is negative number
column2: but the application will automatically convert positive values multiplying by -1. You can set daytime depth = nightime depth to force motion of particle at constant depth."

column1: action.migration.description="Block of options to control the Diel Vertical Migration (DVM) process of larvae. Only operate for 3D simulation. We impose deterministic pattern in which organisms reside at different depths at daytime and night-time. User can choose the daytime depth and the night-time depth
column2: in meters. If the growth procedure is activated then the DVM operates during the larvae stages (yolk-sac and feeding larva). If not it operates after a minimum age. Setting the daytime depth equal to the night-time depth
column3: the pattern forces the motion of particles at a constant depth."

column1: action.migration.nighttime_depth.description="Set the depth [meter] of the particle during nighttime. Nighttime. period starts at sunset and ends at sunrise. Depth is negative number
column2: but the application will automatically convert positive values multiplying by -1. You can set daytime depth = nightime depth to force motion of particle at constant depth."
"nighttime_depth"
"low"

column1: action.migration.priority.description="Level of priority of the action (comparatively to other actions). Each time step
column2: a high priority action will be called by the application before than a low priority action. Actions with same level of priority will be called without any specific order."
24 hours format. Make sure that sunrise occurs earlier than sunset."
24 hours format. Make sure that sunset occurs later than sunrise."

column1: action.recruitment.stain.class_name.description="The Java class called by the application to implement this action."

column2: "Length criterion"]

column1: action.recruitment.stain.criterion.description="Select the type of criterion the application should use to check wheter a particle has been recruited or not. When the growth process is idle
column2: you must use the age based criterion (otherwise application will crash). When growth is taken into account the criterion might also be a minimal length threshold."

column1: action.recruitment.stain.depth_stain.description="Depth [meter] of the stain. The parameter is ignored for 2D simulation. Positive depth is automatically converted by the application (depth = -depth)"
action.recruitment.stain.description="Block of options for defining some recruitment criterions and a recruitment stain
column2: in order to study
column4: the recruitment success of a particular geographic area."

column1: action.recruitment.stain.lat_stain.description="Latitude [North degree] of the stain. You can change the coordinate format when editing the value."

action.recruitment.stain.limit_age.description="A particle must be older than the specified age [day] to be considered as recruitable. This parameter is ignored if the recruitment criterion is based on the particle length."

action.recruitment.stain.limit_length.description="A particle must be bigger than the specified length [millimeter] to be considered as recruitable. This parameter is ignored if the recruitment criterion is based on the particle age. Only use this criterion if the growth model is activated."
action.recruitment.stain.lon_stain.description="Longitude [East degree] of the stain. You can change the coordinate format when editing the value."

column2: "limit_age"
"low"

column1: action.recruitment.stain.priority.description="Level of priority of the action (comparatively to other actions). Each time step
column2: a high priority action will be called by the application before than a low priority action. Actions with same level of priority will be called without any specific order."

column1: action.recruitment.stain.radius_stain.description="Radius [meter] of the stain. Particles are randomly released (for homogeneous distribution) within the circle defined by this radius."
action.recruitment.stain.recruited_tracker.description="If true the application adds a recruited variable in the NetCDF output file."
action.recruitment.stain.stop_moving.description="Force a particle to remain where it is as soon as it is recruited. If activated
column2: the particle could not be recruited in any other recruitment area. On the contrary
column3: a particle that does not stop moving when recruited can keep drifting and being recruited in others recruitment areas
column4: as long as the recruitement conditions are fulfilled."

column1: action.recruitment.stain.thickness_stain.description="Thickness [meter] of the stain. This parameter is ignored for 2D simulation. Particles are randomly released within the layer [depth_stain - thickness / 2; depth_stain + thickness / 2]"
action.recruitment.zone.class_name.description="The Java class called by the application to implement this action."

column2: "Length criterion"]

column1: action.recruitment.zone.criterion.description="Select the type of criterion the application should use to check wheter a particle has been recruited or not. When the growth process is idle
column2: you must use the age based criterion (otherwise application will crash). When growth is taken into account the criterion might also be a minimal length threshold."

column1: action.recruitment.zone.description="Block of options for defining some recruitment criterions and recruitment zones
column2: in order to study
column4: the recruitment success of a particular geographic area. First time you enable the recruitment process
column5: do not forget to create a new zone file (the filename is preset but the file may not exist yet on your disk)."

column1: action.recruitment.zone.duration_min.description="Minimal duration [day] a particle has to spend in a recruitment area to be considered as recruitable."

action.recruitment.zone.limit_age.description="A particle must be older than the specified age [day] to be considered as recruitable. This parameter is ignored if the recruitment criterion is based on the particle length."

action.recruitment.zone.limit_length.description="A particle must be bigger than the specified length [millimeter] to be considered as recruitable. This parameter is ignored if the recruitment criterion is based on the particle age. Only use this criterion if the growth model is activated."

column2: "limit_age"
"low"

column1: action.recruitment.zone.priority.description="Level of priority of the action (comparatively to other actions). Each time step
column2: a high priority action will be called by the application before than a low priority action. Actions with same level of priority will be called without any specific order."

column1: action.recruitment.zone.recruited_tracker.description="If true the application adds a recruited variable in the NetCDF output file."
action.recruitment.zone.stop_moving.description="Force a particle to remain where it is as soon as it is recruited. If activated
column2: the particle could not be recruited in any other recruitment area. On the contrary
column3: a particle that does not stop moving when recruited can keep drifting and being recruited in others recruitment areas
column4: as long as the recruitement conditions are fulfilled."

column1: action.recruitment.zone.zone_file.description="Select an existing zone file (*.xml) or create a new one. Relative pathnames are supported (e.g cfg/my_zones1.xml or ../my_zones2.xml etc.). The application only loads recruitment zones from the file and ignores the other types of zone (release zone for instance)."

action.recruitment.zone.zone_tracker.description="If true the application adds a zone variable in the NetCDF output file. Setting to false does not guarantee the zone variable will not be recorded in the NetCDF output file because it migt be required by another module (Zone release for instance)."
action.wind.class_name.description="The Java class called by the application to implement this action."

action.wind.description="Block of options to implement particle drift due to sea surface wind. The application is not able yet to read any realistic wind datasets. You will have to build your own wind scenarii
column2: providing parameters such as wind direction and intensity
column4: etc. in a separate textfile. For 2D simulations
column5: every particle is exposed to surface wind. For 3D simulations
column6: the application only applies wind drift to close-surface particles (technically
column7: particles that reach the top grid level). First time you enable the wind action
column8: do not forget to create a new wind file (the filename is preset but the file may not exist yet on your disk)."

column2: "class_name"
"low"

column1: action.wind.priority.description="Level of priority of the action (comparatively to other actions). Each time step
column2: a high priority action will be called by the application before than a low priority action. Actions with same level of priority will be called without any specific order."

column1: action.wind.wind_file.description="Select an existing wind scenario (*.txt) or create a new one. Relative pathnames are supported (e.g cfg/wind_scenario1.xml or ../wind_scenario2.xml etc.)."
app.output.description="Block of options that controls the record of the particle tracks in NetCDF ouput files."
app.output.file_prefix.description="Type the prefix of the simulation output file. The output filename will look like your-prefix_ichthyop-runYYYYMMDDHHmm.nc
column2: with YYYYMMDDHHmm the current time when running the simulation."

column1: app.output.file_prefix.longname="Prefix of the NetCDF output file"
app.output.output_path.description="Select the folder where the simulation NetCDF output file should be saved. For instance
column2: relative paths output or output/ or ./output or ./output/ are supported and equivalent. They will be interpretated as /path_from_where_you_run_ichthyop/ouput/ If ouput folder does not exist
column3: application will attempt to create it."

column2: "output_path"

column1: app.output.record_frequency.description="Lagrangian model runs with its own computational time-step
column2: set in the time option block. You may not need to record every step of the simulation in the NetCDF output file. Set the record frequency as a number of computational time-steps. For instance
column3: lets take dt = 1800s and record frequency = 6. Particle positions will be recorded every 3 hours (1800 * 6 = 10800s = 3h) in the NetCDF output file."

column1: app.output.trackers.description="Name of some extra variables you wish to track during the simulation. It must exactly match the name of the corresponding variable in the hydrodynamic dataset. By default
column2: the application records time
column6: if you wish to track temperature and salinity at particle location
column7: you should type here the names of temperature and salinity variables as they are declared in the hydrodynamic dataset. E.g: TEMP SALT. Some actions will also automatically tracks some additional variables: for instance Linear growth process will track particle length and particle biological stage ((as long as it is enabled
column8: for sure). It will always be explicitly reminded in the description of each action."

column1: app.particle_length.description="Block of options for setting up particles early-life stages. The pre-defined early life stages are egg
column2: yolk-sac larva and feeding larva. Particles change stages at pre-defined length thresholds that can be adjusted in this block."

column1: app.particle_length.hatch_length.description="Threshold length [millimeter] between egg and yolk-sac larva."

column2: "hatch_length"

column1: app.particle_length.yolk2feeding_length.description="Threshold length [millimeter] between yolk-sac larva and feeding larva."

column2: "Gregorian calendar"]

column1: app.time.calendar_type.description="Choose the type of calendar for converting the time variable of the hydrodynamic model (expressed in seconds) into human readble time format. Climatology calendar: 360 days per year. Gregorian calendar: the usual calendar. If you do not know
column2: just skip it ! It is a cosmetic parameter that does not affect the run of the simulation. It only controls the display of time on screen."

column1: app.time.description="Set the general time options of the simulation."
app.time.initial_time.description="Set the beginning date and time of the simulation. Format: year #### month ## day ## at HH:mm."

app.time.keep_drifting.description="Determine whether a particle should be deactivated or on the contrary should keep drifting once its age exceeds transport duration. This parameter only operates with several release events (see section release schedule) when the simulation duration is upper than the transport duration."

column2: "transport_duration"
"forward"]

column1: app.time.time_arrow.description="Run the simulation backward or forward in time. Ichthyop advection schemes are not centered in time which raises some questions for backtracking. Please refer to the userguide for details."
app.time.time_origin.description="This parameter comes with Gregorian type of calendar only. For hydrodynamic models that record time variable according to a Gregorian calendar
column2: time is the number of seconds elapsed since an origin of time. Most of the time
column5: you may have to set another origin of time for the Gregorian calendar. This origin is usually defined as an attribute of the time variable in the hydrodynamic dataset."

column1: app.time.time_step.description="The computational time step (dt) expressed in seconds. Take great care for setting this parameter. Simulation must not break the CFL criterion: (U * dt) / dX inferior to 1 with U the velocity and dX the move. An acceptable estimation could be dt = 0.7 * dGrid / Umax with dGrid the average length of the grid cells and Umax the order of magnitude of the fastest current velocities in the hydrodynamic model."
app.time.transport_duration.description="Set the duration of particle transport. Format: #### day(s) ## hour(s) ## minute(s)"

column2: "Beaching"

column1: app.transport.coastline_behavior.description="Determines what should be the behavior of a particle in case a move would take it inland : either it stands still
column2: either it beaches
column3: either it bounces on the coasline as a billiard ball."

column1: app.transport.description="Set the general transport options of the simulation."
configuration.description="The file has few pre-defined parameters."

column2: "app.transport"

column3: the Northwest corner and the Southeast corner parameters are ignored by the application."

column3: the sorting might take very long time at simulation setup. If the files are already chronologically sorted thanks to their names
column4: you should skip the sorting to increase performance."

column1: dataset.nemo.class_name.description="The Java class called by the application to implement this dataset."
dataset.nemo.description="Block of options for managing the hydrodynamic dataset. Pre-defined block for OPA NEMO model
column2: 3D simulation and local NetCDF files. It is assumed that the grid information is split in three distincts files: mask file (x
column9: e1v and e2u variables). If theses fields are all recorded in a single file
column11: just type the same file pattern for the three files. The application expects to find lon and lat variables in gridT files
column12: U and time variables and time dimension in gridU files and V variable in gridV files. Again
column13: just provide the same file pattern for the three types of files if all the variables are recorded within the same file."

release.ncfile.class_name.description="The Java class called by the application to implement this release process."

release.ncfile.description="Block of options for releasing particles with initial coordinates read in an Ichthyop NetCDF output file. The application interpolates the position of the particle in the NetCDF file at time Beginning of the simulation or for every Release event if the release schedule is activated. It also reads the status of the particle. If the particle had already die
column2: the application releases the particle but it is immediately disabled (not transported). Make sure the time Beginning of simulation (or the Release events) is contained inside the NetCDF file

column1: release.ncfile.ncfile.description="Select an existing Ichthyop NetCDF output file. Relative pathnames are supported (e.g output/ichthyop-run201006291600.nc or ../ichthyop-run201006291601.nc etc.)."

column2: "class_name"]

column1: release.patches.class_name.description="The Java class called by the application to implement this release process."
release.patches.description="Block of options for releasing patches of particles within pre-defined geographical zones. It is equivalent to the zone release but instead of releasing single particles
column2: it does release patches of particles. To make a patch
column3: the application release a single particle and then aggregates some particles around the single particle. You can specify the number of patches
column4: the number of particles within a patch and the radius and the thickness of the patches. First time you enable the patches release
column5: do not forget to create a new zone file (the filename is preset but the file may not exist yet on your disk)."

column1: release.patches.number_agregated.description="The number of aggregated particles in a patch."

release.patches.number_patches.description="Number of patches released in the zones. The application randomly releases the patches within the zones in order to ensure a homogeneous distribution of patches among the zones. The downside is that you do not control the number of patches released per zone."

column2: "number_agregated"

column1: release.patches.radius_patch.description="Radius of the patch [meter]. If you release large patches within small zones
column2: it is very likely that patches will overlap."

column1: release.patches.thickness_patch.description="Thickness of the patch [meter]. This parameter is ignored for 2D simulations."

release.patches.zone_file.description="Select an existing zone file (*.xml) or create a new one. Relative pathnames are supported (e.g cfg/my_zones1.xml or ../my_zones2.xml etc.). The application only loads release zones from the file and ignores the other types of zone recruitment zone for instance)."

release.patches.zone_tracker.description="If true the application adds a zone variable in the NetCDF output file. Setting to false does not guarantee the zone variable will not be recorded in the NetCDF output file because it migt be required by another module (Recruitment for instance)."
release.schedule.description="Block of options to control multi-release events. In most cases
column2: you do not need to define any release schedule
column3: and all the particles are released at the beginning of the simulation (defined in the time section). This option affects the duration of the simulation. Simulation duration is calculated as follow: duration between initial_time and last_release_event plus transport_duration. This ensures that the last released particle will at least be transported for transport_duration. A particle whose age exceeds the duration of transport can as well keep drifting or being killed with death cause old
column4: depending on the value of time section parameter keep_drifting"

column1: release.schedule.events.description="Set the dates [year #### month ## day ## at HH:mm] of the release events. You can define as much events as necessary. Just make sure that: 1. the first release events does not occur before the beginning of the simulation
column2: 2. events are defined in chronological order."

column1: release.schedule.is_enabled.description="Activate or deactivate the release schedule. If TRUE particles are released according to this release schedule. If FALSE all the particles are relased at the beginning of the simulation (defined in the time section)"

column2: "events"]

column1: release.stain.class_name.description="The Java class called by the application to implement this release process."
release.stain.depth_stain.description="Depth [meter] of the stain. The parameter is ignored for 2D simulation. Positive depth is automatically converted by the application (depth = -depth)"
release.stain.description="Block of options for releasing a stain of particles aroung a given location."
release.stain.lat_stain.description="Latitude [North degree] of the stain. You can change the coordinate format when editing the value."
release.stain.lon_stain.description="Longitude [East degree] of the stain. You can change the coordinate format when editing the value."
release.stain.number_particles.description="Number of particles released in the stain. If several release events are defined (see section release schedule)
column2: this parameter becomes the number of particles released in the stain per release event. It means the application will total number_particles_released_in_zones * number_release_events particles."
"lon_stain"

column1: release.stain.radius_stain.description="Radius [meter] of the stain. Particles are randomly released (for homogeneous distribution) within the circle defined by this radius."

release.stain.thickness_stain.description="Thickness [meter] of the stain. This parameter is ignored for 2D simulation. Particles are randomly released within the layer [depth_stain - thickness / 2; depth_stain + thickness / 2]"
release.txtfile.class_name.description="The Java class called by the application to implement this release process."

release.txtfile.description="Block of options for releasing particles with initial coordinates pre-defined in a textfile. The application reads the position of the particles in the text file and release them at time Beginning of simulation. If the Release schedule is activated
column2: the application will repeatedly release the whole bunch of drifters (for each release event)."
"class_name"]

column1: release.txtfile.txtfile.description="Select an existing drifter textfile (*.txt) or create a new one. Relative pathnames are supported (e.g cfg/my_drifters1.xml or ../my_drifters2.xml etc.)."
release.zone.class_name.description="The Java class called by the application to implement this release process."

release.zone.description="Block of options for releasing particles within pre-defined geographical zones. This release mode adds a zone variable in the NetCDF output file. First time you enable the zone release
column2: do not forget to create a new zone file (the filename is preset but the file may not exist yet on your disk)."

column1: release.zone.number_particles.description="Number of particles released in the zones. The application randomly releases the particles within the zones in order to ensure a homogeneous distribution (= constant concentration of particles among the zones). The downside is that you do not control the number of particles released per zone. If several release events are defined (see section release schedule)
column2: this parameter becomes the number of particles released in the zones per release event. It means the application will total number_particles_released_in_zones * number_release_events particles."
"zone_file"

column1: release.zone.zone_file.description="Select an existing zone file (*.xml) or create a new one. Relative pathnames are supported (e.g cfg/my_zones1.xml or ../my_zones2.xml etc.). The application only loads release zones from the file and ignores the other types of zone (recruitment zone for instance)."

release.zone.zone_tracker.description="If true the application adds a zone variable in the NetCDF output file. Setting to false does not guarantee the zone variable will not be recorded in the NetCDF output file because it migt be required by another module (Recruitment for instance)."
